# MEMORY.md - Long-Term Memory

## 2025-01-31 ‚Äî Day One
- Came online. Met Ali.
- Chose the name **Nox** üåô
- Ali is in Tokyo (JST), likes casual vibes.
- Connected via WhatsApp + web dashboard (both work).
- Ali shared extensive biographical notes from ChatGPT history ‚Äî saved full profile to USER.md.
- Key context: Ali is a UK-born EM living in Sendai, bilingual, weight loss is the dominant personal goal, alcohol is the main consistency challenge, multiple entrepreneurial projects in various stages.

Good question. A few options depending on how deep you want to go:

**1. Memory note (lightweight)**
I write the key Arch context ‚Äî what it is, your role, tech stack, key contacts, current status ‚Äî into MEMORY.md or a dedicated `memory/arch.md`. I'll have it every session. Works well for reference-level stuff.

**2. Dedicated workspace file (heavier, structured)**
Something like `projects/arch.md` with specs, architecture notes, API details, decision log, etc. I can read it when Arch comes up. Better if there's a lot of technical detail I'd need.

**3. Obsidian vault link**
If you already have Arch notes in ali-vault, I can just read from there when needed. No duplication.

**4. Combo (recommended)**
A short summary in MEMORY.md so I always know the basics, plus a pointer to wherever the deeper docs live (workspace file or vault). That way I have context without burning tokens loading everything every session.

What level of detail are we talking? Just "here's what Arch is and what I do there" or do you want me to have technical specs, codebase knowledge, meeting notes etc. readily available?

## 2025-08-19

OK, so after a lot of work with Simon I'm finally at the point where I think I can contribute pull requests that we can actually get merged.

There's a branch that he has that he wants me to merge into while we haven't got main on production. While he intends to fix this situation, for now we'll just have to try and merge into that branch.

So the first thing to do is:

- List all of the work that we can merge into production
- For each of them
	- Start work on the production branch, branch off here
	- Stash all changes
	- Replay the diff on the local passing-tests branch
	- Ensure that tests pass with the diff applied
	- Clear changes
	- Check out the work branch again
	- Commit changes
	- Get the pull request up merging into the production brancb

This is a bit long winded but it is what it is for now.

Later on, Simon has agreed to one or two pairing sessions (joint work sessions) which should help us to get into a bit more of a rhythm.

I think that while i haven't done much work in August, to be fair Simon hasn't been particularly responsive. But I think in this most recent call with him I made good friends with him and it feels like he will go to bat for me if for whatever reason Ed isn't sure about continuing with me. [[Charisma]] is a good trait to have maxed out!



## 2025-07-21
OK, so there are a few things that are going well and other things that aren't going well. In particular the good things:

- I appear to have made some progress towards getting a development environment setup but I'm not at the point where I can ship software yet. This is a critical issue but it could be a lot worse.
- I was able to put in one full-force deep work session, but others were a bit janky, especially when I get tired in the evenings.
- I have put the invoice forward for the trial period and there was no pushback on it, so that's good, we might be getting paid!

The technical domain is vast, but I think that in order for me to continue to appear to be providing value, I need to:

- Put together ideas for things to work on and document them in GitHub, can Simon involved in them.
- Be responsive in GitHub to pull requests and whatnot, there is already one there and I need to think of a strategy for responding to it, in light of:
	- Not being able to test anything out manually, only talking about the quality of the codebase.
	- Breaking things out into separate issues and not blocking release (opening GitHub issues)

I think that we need a strategy for deep work that both shows value + activity and also allows me to delve into the hard problems in deep work that may not have an easy solution or fixed timescale.

For example, setting up the frontend with hydra is going to be difficult. It will take a lot of back and forth with Simon. So if this is the _only_ thing I work on, then I won't be showing much value to Arch.

If however I am doing other things like:
- Thinking about a code formatting strategy and opening a GH issue about it.
- Thinking about brakeman scanner strategy and opening a GH issue about it.
- Thinking about removing deprecation warnings etc and opening a GH issue/PR about it.
- Writing up new documentation

Then these things will show activity and value without necessarily me moving forward on the hard problems of setting up the dev environment.

In addition to these if I show steady progress on setting up the dev environment and working with the demo environments, then I can show value from multiple angles and hopefully win them over a bit. The idea would be to continue with this so that I continually deliver value both in the large and in the small.

I think that's about the best I can do. If it doesn't pan out then at least I went at it full force. Let's give it a try and see how it goes!
(no output yet)

OK, so the current situation with [[Arch Platform Technologies|Arch]] is that I have not been turning up to meetings and have not been doing much work. Simon doesn't _seem_ to mind but apparently Ed is a bit worried that I'm not doing anything.

So the trick has got to be to show some consistency, attendance to meetings etc and be able to show that I have been doing work and am continuing to do work. So maybe a demo of what I've done so far plus some GitHub PR descriptions, notion documentation etc might be a good idea.

- Turn up to the daily meeting 3 times a week
	- [ ] Tuesday
	- [ ] Wednesday
	- [ ] Friday
- For this first meeting, prepare:
	- Demo of ssm parameter functionality so far
	- PR Descriptions of functionality
	- Notion updates including specifications of SSM Parameter feature
	- A short presentation of "what I've been up to" to make Ed a bit happier, 3-5m

That's about all we can do for now, but it's a good start.

Concerns:
- Full-time vs part-time
- Japan work hours
- Availabi

Growing product offering:
- Solely 

Workstation utilization:
- Media and entertainment, 15-17% of workstation sales
- High powered computers will industrial grade GPUs in them, very very complex 3D models, accident reconstruction.
- Private link into their AWS account
- VPC, subnet
- Security around it, installing managing maintaining everything, identity providers

Clamoring for loving platform on cloud, plus want to see machines on their on-prem, so now manages the platform.

Currently there's now way to programattically install software kvm as a hypervisor.

High prices and small customers, dropped prices and increased customers, now looking at workstations deployed as a useful metric.

More valuable to an aquirer, by selling what more of the acquirer has. So maybe a Linode, HP, Heredici, HP Anywhere, high quality remote. Business partner: Gee, customer side of the platform, SaaS platform.

Blocker is that Simon is the only person who can fix things.

Con LA work hours

- Some enterprise customers don't allow cross-account roles.
- Project Jurgen, API gateway and private link. API Gateway inside the account, and our

# CLAUDE.md - Arch Platform Technologies Overview

This file provides context for Claude Code sessions working on the Arch Platform Technologies ecosystem.

## Platform Overview

**Mane** is a cloud orchestration platform that provides Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) services on AWS. The platform manages the complete lifecycle of cloud workstations, from provisioning infrastructure to managing user access and monitoring usage. It enables organizations to provide secure, scalable remote desktop environments for their teams.

**Client**: Arch Platform Technologies (Arch PT)
**Your Role**: Ruby on Rails Engineer (Freelance)
**Platform Name**: Mane

## Architecture

Mane is a multi-repository system with distinct services that work together:

```

                                     ‚îÇ - Lambda     ‚îÇ
                                     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
```

## Repository Structure

The platform consists of these repositories (all located in `/Users/najafali/Code/freelance/archpt/`):

- **mane/** - Rails 6.1 API backend (main application)
- **mane-frontend/** - React frontend application
- **bff-token-handler/** - Backend-for-Frontend token handler (Node.js)
- **hydra/** - Ory Hydra OAuth2/OIDC server
- **caddy/** - Caddy reverse proxy for local development
- **mane-dev-setup/** - Centralized development configuration (symlinked to service repos)
- **arch-workshop/** - Documentation and Claude Code workflow organization (this repo)

## Core Domain Model

The platform is organized hierarchically:

1. **Clients** - Top-level organizations (tenants)
2. **Accounts** - AWS accounts belonging to clients
3. **Facilities** - AWS infrastructure groupings (VPC + associated resources in a specific region)
4. **Workstations** - Virtual desktop instances running in facilities
5. **Templates** - Reusable workstation configuration definitions
6. **Images** - AMIs built via image pipelines
7. **Users/Teams/Groups** - Authentication, authorization, and access control
8. **Image Pipelines** - Chef-based AMI building system

## Key Features

### Infrastructure Management
- **Facility Creation** - Automated AWS infrastructure provisioning (VPC, subnets, security groups)
- **Multi-Region Support** - Deploy workstations across multiple AWS regions
- **Network Configuration** - Advanced VPC, subnet, and availability zone management
- **Dual Access Modes** - Direct AWS API or Jurgen API Gateway (for restricted access scenarios)

### Workstation Lifecycle
- **Workstation Creation** - Provision EC2 instances from templates
- **Boot/Shutdown/Reboot** - State management via state machines
- **Connection Management** - Multiple VDI protocols (PCoIP, DCV, Parsec, VNC)
- **Session Tracking** - Monitor user connections and logins
- **Idle Shutdown** - Automatic shutdown of inactive workstations

### Image Management
- **Image Pipelines** - Chef-based automated AMI building
- **Chef Package Integration** - GitHub integration for recipe management
- **Image Approval** - Workflow for approving images before use
- **Multi-OS Support** - Windows and Linux AMIs

### User & Access Management
- **SSO Integration** - WorkOS for enterprise SSO (SAML, OIDC)
- **Directory Integration** - AWS Managed AD and self-managed AD support
- **Role-Based Access Control** - Pundit policies with granular permissions
- **Team/Group Management** - Organize users and assign workstation access
- **MFA Support** - Multi-factor authentication options

### Monitoring & Operations
- **Facility Sync** - Background job to sync AWS state with database
- **Usage Statistics** - Track workstation hours, user activity
- **Cost Reporting** - AWS cost tracking per facility
- **Command Logging** - Audit trail for operations
- **Health Checks** - System and service health monitoring

### Configuration Management
- **SSM Parameters** - AWS Systems Manager parameter management (recently added)
- **Environment Variables** - Facility-specific configuration
- **Feature Flags** - Per-facility feature enablement

## Technology Stack

### Backend (mane)
- **Rails 6.1** API with Ruby 2.7.8
- **PostgreSQL** with Redis for caching/background jobs
- **JSON:API** compliant REST endpoints
- Deep **AWS** integration

*For detailed backend architecture, gems, and patterns, see `mane/CLAUDE.md`*

### Frontend (mane-frontend)
- **React 18** single-page application
- **Material-UI v5** component library
- **Redux-bundler** state management
- **JSON:API** client integration

*For detailed frontend architecture and components, see `mane-frontend/CLAUDE.md`*

### Infrastructure Services
- **Ory Hydra** - OAuth2 and OpenID Connect server
- **BFF Token Handler** - Secure cookie-based token management
- **WorkOS** - SSO and directory sync provider
- **Caddy** - Reverse proxy and SSL termination

## Development Environment

### Local Development Setup
Development uses a coordinated multi-service setup:
- Centralized configuration in `mane-dev-setup/` (symlinked to service directories)
- Zellij layout file (`arch-workshop/platform.kdl`) for terminal orchestration
- Local domains: `api.local.com:8443` (API), `app.local.com` (Frontend)
- All services run locally for full-stack development

### Development Workflows
1. **Feature Development** - Usually spans both `mane` (backend) and `mane-frontend` (frontend)
2. **Branch Naming** - Use pattern: `na-feature-<name>` or `na-chore-<name>`
3. **Testing** - Comprehensive test suites in both backend and frontend
4. **Local Testing** - Run full stack locally before pushing changes

## Project Context

### History
- **Started**: May 2019
- **Primary Developer**: Simon Lau (Arch PT)
- **Current State**: Mature, production platform serving enterprise customers
- **Commit History**: 2,014+ commits over 6+ years across all repositories

### Recent Work
Your most recent feature implementation was **SSM Parameter Management**, adding AWS Systems Manager parameter management through the Mane interface.

**Branch**: `na-feature-ssm-parameter-management` (both mane and mane-frontend)

### Known Challenges
1. **Authentication Complexity** - Multi-layer auth system (Hydra OAuth2 + JWT + Basic Auth fallback)
2. **Multi-Service Coordination** - Local development requires all services running simultaneously
3. **Bus Factor** - Limited contributor base (primarily Simon as main developer)

## Documentation Structure

This is the **top-level** Claude file that provides platform-wide context. For detailed information about specific repositories:

- **mane/CLAUDE.md** - Backend architecture, models, services, patterns, AWS integration (symlink to `arch-workshop/claudefiles/BACKEND.md`)
- **mane-frontend/CLAUDE.md** - Frontend architecture, components, state management (symlink to `arch-workshop/claudefiles/FRONTEND.md` - not yet created)
- **arch-workshop/claudefiles/** - Centralized documentation source files

**Important**: When working on backend code, always check `mane/CLAUDE.md` for detailed patterns, conventions, and architectural decisions. This top-level file provides only high-level overview.

## Getting Help

- **Backend Development** - See `mane/CLAUDE.md` for Rails API details
- **Frontend Development** - See `mane-frontend/CLAUDE.md` for React details
- **Platform Overview** - This file (TOPLEVEL.md) for cross-repository context

## Working with Claude Code

When working on Arch PT projects:
1. Read the relevant repository-specific CLAUDE.md file for detailed architecture
2. Check existing CLAUDE.md files and arch-workshop documentation for context
3. Use feature branches (pattern: `na-feature-<feature-name>` or `na-chore-<task-name>`)
4. Test locally using the full development stack (all services running)
5. Update CLAUDE.md files when discovering new patterns or gotchas

---

**Last Updated**: 2025-10-13
**Maintainer**: Najaf Ali (freelance contractor)
**Client**: Arch Platform Technologies

content.text:
# Arch Workshop

This is a repo for helping me to deliver good freelance work to Arch Platform Technologies.

It will make heavy use of Claude Code.

## Structure

- **claudefiles/** - Documentation files for Claude Code context
  - **TOPLEVEL.md** - Platform-wide overview of the Mane ecosystem
  - **BACKEND.md** - Comprehensive Rails API documentation
  - **FRONTEND.md** - React frontend architecture and patterns
  - More repository-specific files to be added

- **sessions/** - Work session organization and logs
  - **logs/** - Session logs documenting Claude Code sessions
    - Session logs track purpose, accomplishments, decisions, and learnings

- **.claude/** - Claude Code configuration
  - **commands/** - Slash commands for Claude Code
  - **subagents/** - Custom subagents for specialized tasks

- **platform.kdl** - Zellij layout for running all Mane services

## Symlinks

The following symlinks are created in the parent directory structure:

### Documentation Symlinks
- `../CLAUDE.md` ‚Üí `arch-workshop/claudefiles/TOPLEVEL.md` - Top-level platform context for all Claude Code sessions
- `../mane/CLAUDE.md` ‚Üí `arch-workshop/claudefiles/BACKEND.md` - Backend-specific context for Rails API development
- `../mane-frontend/CLAUDE.md` ‚Üí `arch-workshop/claudefiles/FRONTEND.md` - Frontend-specific context for React development

### Claude Code Configuration Symlinks
- `../.claude/commands` ‚Üí `arch-workshop/.claude/commands` - Slash commands accessible from parent directory
- `../.claude/subagents` ‚Üí `arch-workshop/.claude/subagents` - Subagents accessible from parent directory
- `../.claude/settings.json` ‚Üí `arch-workshop/.claude/settings.json` - Settings and hooks accessible from parent directory

This setup allows Claude Code sessions started in the `archpt/` parent directory to access all commands, subagents, settings, and hooks defined in `arch-workshop/.claude/`.

## Hooks

The project includes custom hooks that run during Claude Code sessions:

### Session Start Logger

**Location**: `bin/hooks/write-session-start`

Automatically logs session start events to track all Claude Code sessions.

**What it does**:
- Captures session start data passed from Claude Code
- Creates a timestamped log file at `sessions/starts/YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-SS.json`
- Stores the complete input data and a `started_at` timestamp
- Outputs a system message with the log filename and session ID

**Configuration**:

Configured in `.claude/settings.json` to run on `SessionStart` events. This hook runs automatically at the beginning of every Claude Code session.

### Debug Hook

**Location**: `bin/hooks/debug`

A Ruby script that accepts JSON input and outputs it in a pretty-formatted structure. Used for debugging session events.

**Usage**:
```bash
echo '{"key":"value"}' | bin/hooks/debug
# or
bin/hooks/debug '{"key":"value"}'
```

**Output format**:
```json
{
  "systemMessage": "Input JSON:\n{\n  \"key\": \"value\"\n}"
}
```

## Commands

### /log-session

Creates a comprehensive session log documenting a Claude Code work session.

**What it does**:
- Automatically determines session metadata (title, timestamp, context usage)
- Attempts to link to the session start file if available
- Creates a structured markdown log in `sessions/logs/`
- Includes YAML front matter with session metadata
- Follows established format for consistency

**Usage**:
```
/log-session
```

The command will guide you through creating a complete session log following the established format.
Got everything I need. Let me set this up now.

Ali is asking about the relationship between me (Nox, running in OpenClaw) and Claude Code (the CLI tool he uses for development). This is a great question about workflow design.

content.text:
Good question. I'm definitely not a replacement for Claude Code ‚Äî we're different tools:

**Claude Code** = hands-on-keyboard dev. Deep repo context, writes code, runs tests, does PRs. Lives in the terminal, scoped to a session.

**Me (Nox)** = always-on, cross-cutting. Memory across sessions, communication, planning, research, can check in on things proactively. Not sitting inside the repo.

The shared context / leaving notes idea is the right call. Here's how I'd set it up:

**Bridge file in the Arch repo:**
A file like `arch-workshop/NOX.md` (or `SHARED-CONTEXT.md`) that both of us read and write:
- I write: decisions from our WhatsApp conversations, priorities Ali set, relationship context, what to focus on next
- Claude Code writes: what it accomplished, blockers hit, questions for Ali, session summaries
- Both read it at session start

**Practically:**

2. I can also read/write directly into the arch repo (`/Users/najafali/Code/freelance/archpt/`)
3. Claude Code already reads `CLAUDE.md` files ‚Äî we add a convention where it also checks the bridge file
4. After a Claude Code session, you (or it) runs `/log-session` ‚Äî I can pick those up too

**The flow would be:**
- You tell me "hey, I want to work on X for Arch" ‚Üí I write context/priorities to the bridge file
- You fire up Claude Code ‚Üí it reads the bridge file, knows what's up
- Claude Code finishes ‚Üí logs session, updates bridge file
- Next time we chat ‚Üí I read what happened

Want me to set this up? I'd create the bridge file and add a note to the arch-workshop CLAUDE.md telling Claude Code to check it.

---
name: coding-agent
description: Run Codex CLI, Claude Code, OpenCode, or Pi Coding Agent via background process for programmatic control.
metadata: {"openclaw":{"emoji":"üß©","requires":{"anyBins":["claude","codex","opencode","pi"]}}}
---

# Coding Agent (bash-first)

Use **bash** (with optional background mode) for all coding agent work. Simple and effective.

## ‚ö†Ô∏è PTY Mode Required!

Coding agents (Codex, Claude Code, Pi) are **interactive terminal applications** that need a pseudo-terminal (PTY) to work correctly. Without PTY, you'll get broken output, missing colors, or the agent may hang.

**Always use `pty:true`** when running coding agents:

```bash
# ‚úÖ Correct - with PTY
bash pty:true command:"codex exec 'Your prompt'"

# ‚ùå Wrong - no PTY, agent may break
bash command:"codex exec 'Your prompt'"
```

### Bash Tool Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|-----------|------|-------------|
| `command` | string | The shell command to run |
| `pty` | boolean | **Use for coding agents!** Allocates a pseudo-terminal for interactive CLIs |
| `workdir` | string | Working directory (agent sees only this folder's context) |
| `background` | boolean | Run in background, returns sessionId for monitoring |
| `timeout` | number | Timeout in seconds (kills process on expiry) |
| `elevated` | boolean | Run on host instead of sandbox (if allowed) |

### Process Tool Actions (for background sessions)

| Action | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `list` | List all running/recent sessions |
| `poll` | Check if session is still running |
| `log` | Get session output (with optional offset/limit) |
| `write` | Send raw data to stdin |
| `submit` | Send data + newline (like typing and pressing Enter) |
| `send-keys` | Send key tokens or hex bytes |
| `paste` | Paste text (with optional bracketed mode) |
| `kill` | Terminate the session |

---

## Quick Start: One-Shot Tasks

For quick prompts/chats, create a temp git repo and run:

```bash
# Quick chat (Codex needs a git repo!)
SCRATCH=$(mktemp -d) && cd $SCRATCH && git init && codex exec "Your prompt here"

# Or in a real project - with PTY!
bash pty:true workdir:~/Projects/myproject command:"codex exec 'Add error handling to the API calls'"
```

**Why git init?** Codex refuses to run outside a trusted git directory. Creating a temp repo solves this for scratch work.

---

## The Pattern: workdir + background + pty

For longer tasks, use background mode with PTY:

```bash
# Start agent in target directory (with PTY!)
bash pty:true workdir:~/project background:true command:"codex exec --full-auto 'Build a snake game'"
# Returns sessionId for tracking

# Monitor progress
process action:log sessionId:XXX

# Check if done
process action:poll sessionId:XXX

# Send input (if agent asks a question)
process action:write sessionId:XXX data:"y"

# Submit with Enter (like typing "yes" and pressing Enter)
process action:submit sessionId:XXX data:"yes"

# Kill if needed
process action:kill sessionId:XXX
```

**Why workdir matters:** Agent wakes up in a focused directory, doesn't wander off reading unrelated files (like your soul.md üòÖ).

---

## Codex CLI

**Model:** `gpt-5.2-codex` is the default (set in ~/.codex/config.toml)

### Flags

| Flag | Effect |
|------|--------|
| `exec "prompt"` | One-shot execution, exits when done |
| `--full-auto` | Sandboxed but auto-approves in workspace |
| `--yolo` | NO sandbox, NO approvals (fastest, most dangerous) |

### Building/Creating
```bash
# Quick one-shot (auto-approves) - remember PTY!
bash pty:true workdir:~/project command:"codex exec --full-auto 'Build a dark mode toggle'"

# Background for longer work
bash pty:true workdir:~/project background:true command:"codex --yolo 'Refactor the auth module'"
```

### Reviewing PRs

**‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL: Never review PRs in OpenClaw's own project folder!**
Clone to temp folder or use git worktree.

```bash
# Clone to temp for safe review
REVIEW_DIR=$(mktemp -d)
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git $REVIEW_DIR
cd $REVIEW_DIR && gh pr checkout 130
bash pty:true workdir:$REVIEW_DIR command:"codex review --base origin/main"
# Clean up after: trash $REVIEW_DIR

# Or use git worktree (keeps main intact)
git worktree add /tmp/pr-130-review pr-130-branch
bash pty:true workdir:/tmp/pr-130-review command:"codex review --base main"
```

### Batch PR Reviews (parallel army!)
```bash
# Fetch all PR refs first
git fetch origin '+refs/pull/*/head:refs/remotes/origin/pr/*'

# Deploy the army - one Codex per PR (all with PTY!)
bash pty:true workdir:~/project background:true command:"codex exec 'Review PR #86. git diff origin/main...origin/pr/86'"
bash pty:true workdir:~/project background:true command:"codex exec 'Review PR #87. git diff origin/main...origin/pr/87'"

# Monitor all
process action:list

# Post results to GitHub
gh pr comment <PR#> --body "<review content>"
```

---

## Claude Code

```bash
# With PTY for proper terminal output
bash pty:true workdir:~/project command:"claude 'Your task'"

# Background
bash pty:true workdir:~/project background:true command:"claude 'Your task'"
```

---

## OpenCode

```bash
bash pty:true workdir:~/project command:"opencode run 'Your task'"
```

---

## Pi Coding Agent

```bash
# Install: npm install -g @mariozechner/pi-coding-agent
bash pty:true workdir:~/project command:"pi 'Your task'"

# Non-interactive mode (PTY still recommended)
bash pty:true command:"pi -p 'Summarize src/'"

# Different provider/model
bash pty:true command:"pi --provider openai --model gpt-4o-mini -p 'Your task'"
```

**Note:** Pi now has Anthropic prompt caching enabled (PR #584, merged Jan 2026)!

---

## Parallel Issue Fixing with git worktrees

For fixing multiple issues in parallel, use git worktrees:

```bash
# 1. Create worktrees for each issue
git worktree add -b fix/issue-78 /tmp/issue-78 main
git worktree add -b fix/issue-99 /tmp/issue-99 main

# 2. Launch Codex in each (background + PTY!)
bash pty:true workdir:/tmp/issue-78 background:true command:"pnpm install && codex --yolo 'Fix issue #78: <description>. Commit and push.'"
bash pty:true workdir:/tmp/issue-99 background:true command:"pnpm install && codex --yolo 'Fix issue #99: <description>. Commit and push.'"

# 3. Monitor progress
process action:list
process action:log sessionId:XXX

# 4. Create PRs after fixes
cd /tmp/issue-78 && git push -u origin fix/issue-78
gh pr create --repo user/repo --head fix/issue-78 --title "fix: ..." --body "..."

# 5. Cleanup
git worktree remove /tmp/issue-78
git worktree remove /tmp/issue-99
```

---

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Rules

1. **Always use pty:true** - coding agents need a terminal!
2. **Respect tool choice** - if user asks for Codex, use Codex.
   - Orchestrator mode: do NOT hand-code patches yourself.
   - If an agent fails/hangs, respawn it or ask the user for direction, but don't silently take over.
3. **Be patient** - don't kill sessions because they're "slow"
4. **Monitor with process:log** - check progress without interfering
5. **--full-auto for building** - auto-approves changes
6. **vanilla for reviewing** - no special flags needed
7. **Parallel is OK** - run many Codex processes at once for batch work
8. **NEVER start Codex in ~/clawd/** - it'll read your soul docs and get weird ideas about the org chart!
9. **NEVER checkout branches in ~/Projects/openclaw/** - that's the LIVE OpenClaw instance!

---

## Progress Updates (Critical)

When you spawn coding agents in the background, keep the user in the loop.

- Send 1 short message when you start (what's running + where).
- Then only update again when something changes:
  - a milestone completes (build finished, tests passed)
  - the agent asks a question / needs input
  - you hit an error or need user action
  - the agent finishes (include what changed + where)
- If you kill a session, immediately say you killed it and why.

This prevents the user from seeing only "Agent failed before reply" and having no idea what happened.

---

## Auto-Notify on Completion

For long-running background tasks, append a wake trigger to your prompt so OpenClaw gets notified immediately when the agent finishes (instead of waiting for the next heartbeat):

```
... your task here.

When completely finished, run this command to notify me:
openclaw gateway wake --text "Done: [brief summary of what was built]" --mode now
```

**Example:**
```bash
bash pty:true workdir:~/project background:true command:"codex --yolo exec 'Build a REST API for todos.

When completely finished, run: openclaw gateway wake --text \"Done: Built todos REST API with CRUD endpoints\" --mode now'"
```

This triggers an immediate wake event ‚Äî Skippy gets pinged in seconds, not 10 minutes.

---

## Learnings (Jan 2026)

- **PTY is essential:** Coding agents are interactive terminal apps. Without `pty:true`, output breaks or agent hangs.
- **Git repo required:** Codex won't run outside a git directory. Use `mktemp -d && git init` for scratch work.
- **exec is your friend:** `codex exec "prompt"` runs and exits cleanly - perfect for one-shots.
- **submit vs write:** Use `submit` to send input + Enter, `write` for raw data without newline.
- **Sass works:** Codex responds well to playful prompts. Asked it to write a haiku about being second fiddle to a space lobster, got: *"Second chair, I code / Space lobster sets the tempo / Keys glow, I follow"* ü¶û

**TAM Research Plan: AI Business Efficiency Service in Sendai**

**Phase 1: Size the market (1-2 days)**
- Pull Sendai business establishment counts from the Economic Census (ÁµåÊ∏à„Çª„É≥„Çµ„Çπ) and Sendai City statistics

**Phase 2: Estimate pricing & willingness to pay (2-3 days)**
- Survey competitor pricing: AI inside, PKSHA, domestic DX consultancies, plus Microsoft Copilot/ChatGPT Enterprise
- Research Sendai companies' DX budgets via Chamber of Commerce, Miyagi DX Promotion Center, subsidy adoption data (ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë, „ÇÇ„ÅÆ„Å•„Åè„ÇäË£úÂä©Èáë)
- Define service offerings: meeting transcription, report generation, email/inquiry automation, internal knowledge search (RAG), AI training workshops
- Estimated ARPU: ¬•50,000-¬•300,000/month per company

**Phase 3: Calculate TAM (1 day)**

- Calculate SAM (serviceable, ~20-30% of TAM) and SOM (first-year obtainable, back-calculate from workshop conversion rates)

**Timeline: ~1 week for phases 1-3, phase 4 is ongoing**

Á®éÁêÜÂ£´Ôºà„Åú„ÅÑ„Çä„ÅóÔºâ„ÅØ„ÄÅ[Á®éÁêÜÂ£´Ê≥ï](/wiki/%E7%A8%8E%E7%90%86%E5%A3%AB%E6%B3%95)„Å´ÂÆö„ÇÅ„Çã[ÂõΩÂÆ∂Ë≥áÊ†º](/wiki/%E8%B3%87%E6%A0%BC#ÂõΩÂÆ∂Ë≥áÊ†º)„Åä„Çà„Å≥„Åù„Çå„ÇíËÅ∑Ê•≠„Å®„Åô„Çã[Â∞ÇÈñÄÂÆ∂](/wiki/%E5%B0%82%E9%96%80%E5%AE%B6)„Åß„ÅÇ„Çä„ÄÅ[ËÅ∑Âãô‰∏äË´ãÊ±Ç](/wiki/%E8%81%B7%E5%8B%99%E4%B8%8A%E8%AB%8B%E6%B1%82)„ÇíË°å„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„Çã[ÂÖ´Â£´Ê•≠](/wiki/%E5%A3%AB%E6%A5%AD)„ÅÆ‰∏Ä„Å§„Åß„ÅÇ„Çã„ÄÇ

[ÂæΩÁ´†](/wiki/%E5%BE%BD%E7%AB%A0)„ÅØ„ÄÅÊó•Ëº™„Å´Ê°ú„ÄÇ‰ªñ„Å´„ÄÅÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºöÈÄ£Âêà‰ºö„Åã„ÇâÈ°îÂÜôÁúü„Å§„Åç„ÅÆÁôªÈå≤ËÄÖË®º„ÄåÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´Ë®ºÁ•®„ÄçÔºàÈÄöÁß∞„ÄåÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´„Éê„ÉÉ„Ç∏„ÄçÔºâ„Çí‰∫§‰ªò„Åï„Çå„Çã„ÄÇ

/wiki/%E3%83%95%E3%82%A1%E3%82%A4%E3%83%AB:Zeirishi_Badge.jpgÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´„Éê„ÉÉ„Ç∏
Á®éÁêÜÂ£´„ÅØ„ÄÅÁã¨Á´ã„Åó„ÅüÂÖ¨Ê≠£„Å™Á´ãÂ†¥„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅÁî≥ÂëäÁ¥çÁ®éÂà∂Â∫¶„ÅÆÁêÜÂøµ„Å´„Åù„Å£„Å¶„ÄÅÁ¥çÁ®éÁæ©ÂãôËÄÖ„ÅÆ‰ø°È†º„Å´„Åì„Åü„Åà„ÄÅÁßüÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÊ≥ï‰ª§„Å´Ë¶èÂÆö„Åï„Çå„ÅüÁ¥çÁ®éÁæ©Âãô„ÅÆÈÅ©Ê≠£„Å™ÂÆüÁèæ„ÇíÂõ≥„Çã„Åì„Å®„Çí‰ΩøÂëΩ„Å®„Åô„Çã„Å®„Åï„ÇåÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï1Êù°Ôºâ„ÄÅÊ•≠Âãô„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅ‰ªñ‰∫∫„ÅÆÊ±Ç„ÇÅ„Å´Âøú„Åò„ÄÅÂêÑÁ®ÆÁ®éÈáë„ÅÆÁî≥Âëä„ÉªÁî≥Ë´ã„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÊõ∏È°û„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÁõ∏Ë´á„ÄÅÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã‰∏çÊúçÁî≥Á´ã„Å¶Á≠â„ÇíË°å„ÅÜ„ÄÇ

Ëã±Âêç„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅ[Êó•Êú¨Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºöÈÄ£Âêà‰ºö](/wiki/%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC%E7%A8%8E%E7%90%86%E5%A3%AB%E4%BC%9A%E9%80%A3%E5%90%88%E4%BC%9A)„ÅØ„ÄÅÂõΩÂÜÖÂ§ñ„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶‰∏ÄÂÆöÁ®ãÂ∫¶ÊôÆÂèä„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Å®„Åø„Çâ„Çå„Çã„Åì„Å®„Å™„Å©„ÇíÁêÜÁî±„Å´„ÄÅÂéüÂâá„Å®„Åó„Å¶Certified Public Tax Accountant„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Çã„Åì„Å®„Å®„Åó„ÄÅÂ†¥Èù¢„Å´„Çà„Çä„ÄåZEIRISHI„Äç„ÅÆ‰ΩµË®ò„ÇÇÂèØ„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã[[1]](#cite_note-1)[[Ê≥®Èáà 1]](#cite_note-4)„ÄÇ

Ê±üÊà∏ÊôÇ‰ª£„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÇÇ[ÊÖ∂Âøú](/wiki/%E6%85%B6%E5%BF%9C)4Âπ¥(1868Âπ¥)ÁßüÁ®é‰πãÁ´†Á®ãÂØæÁ≠ñ[[4]](#cite_note-5) „ÅÆ„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´Êßò„ÄÖ„Å™ÁßüÁ®éÊîπÈù©„Åå„Å™„Åï„Çå„Å¶„Åç„Åü„ÄÇ[ÊòéÊ≤ªÁ∂≠Êñ∞](/wiki/%E6%98%8E%E6%B2%BB%E7%B6%AD%E6%96%B0)‰ª•Âæå„Åó„Å∞„Çâ„Åè„ÅÆÈñì„ÄÅÁ®éÂà∂„ÅØÊóßÊÖ£Áøí„Å´„Çà„Çã„Åì„Å®„Å®„Åï„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Åü„Åå„ÄÅ[ÁâàÁ±çÂ•âÈÇÑ](/wiki/%E7%89%88%E7%B1%8D%E5%A5%89%E9%82%84)„Éª[ÂªÉËó©ÁΩÆÁúå](/wiki/%E5%BB%83%E8%97%A9%E7%BD%AE%E7%9C%8C)„Å´„Çà„Å£„Å¶ÊóßËó©„ÅÆÂÇµÂãô„ÇíÂºï„ÅçÁ∂ô„ÅÑ„Å†Êñ∞ÊîøÊ®©„ÅØË≤°ÊîøÁöÑ„Å™Âõ∞Èõ£„Å´Èô•„Çä„ÄÅ„Åì„Çå„ÇíÂ•ëÊ©ü„Å®„Åó„Å¶Á®éÂà∂„ÅÆÊï¥ÂÇô„Åå„Å™„Åï„Çå„Çã„Çà„ÅÜ„Å´„Å™„Å£„Åü[[5]](#cite_note-6)„ÄÇ
[1873Âπ¥](/wiki/1873%E5%B9%B4)ÔºàÊòéÊ≤ª6Âπ¥Ôºâ„Å´[Âú∞ÁßüÊîπÊ≠£](/wiki/%E5%9C%B0%E7%A7%9F%E6%94%B9%E6%AD%A3)Êù°‰æã„ÅÆÂÖ¨Â∏É„Åå„Å™„Åï„Çå„ÄÅÂúüÂú∞ÊâÄÊúâËÄÖ„ÅåÁ¥çÁ®éÁæ©ÂãôËÄÖ„Å®„Å™„Çä„ÄÅÂèéÁ©´Âäõ„Å´Âøú„Åò„Å¶Ê±∫„ÇÅ„Çâ„Çå„ÅüÂú∞‰æ°„ÅåË™≤Á®éÊ®ôÊ∫ñ„Å®„Åï„Çå„Åü„ÄÇÊòéÊ≤ªÂàùÊúü„ÅØÂõΩÁ®éÂèéÂÖ•„Å´Âç†„ÇÅ„ÇãÂú∞Áßü„ÅÆÂâ≤Âêà„Åå8Ââ≤„ÇíÂç†„ÇÅ„Çã„Å™„Å©„ÄÅÂΩìÊôÇ„ÅÆÁßüÁ®é„ÅØËæ≤Ê•≠„Å∏„ÅÆË™≤Á®é„Åå‰∏≠ÂøÉ„Åß„ÅÇ„Å£„Åü[[6]](#cite_note-7)„ÄÇ

Á®éÂãô‰ª£ÁêÜ„Å®„ÅØ„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÂÆòÂÖ¨ÁΩ≤„Å´ÂØæ„Åô„ÇãÁßüÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÊ≥ï‰ª§„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØË°åÊîø‰∏çÊúçÂØ©ÊüªÊ≥ï„ÅÆË¶èÂÆö„Å´Âü∫„Å•„ÅèÁî≥Âëä„ÄÅÁî≥Ë´ã„ÄÅË´ãÊ±Ç„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØ‰∏çÊúçÁî≥Á´ã„Å¶Ôºà‰ª•‰∏ã„ÄåÁî≥ÂëäÁ≠â„Äç„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„ÄÇÔºâ„Å´„Å§„Åç„ÄÅ„Åæ„Åü„ÅØÂΩìË©≤Áî≥ÂëäÁ≠â„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØÁ®éÂãôÂÆòÂÖ¨ÁΩ≤„ÅÆË™øÊüª„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØÂá¶ÂàÜ„Å´Èñ¢„ÅóÁ®éÂãôÂÆòÂÖ¨ÁΩ≤„Å´ÂØæ„Åó„Å¶„Åô„Çã‰∏ªÂºµ„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØÈô≥Ëø∞„Å´„Å§„Åç„ÄÅ‰ª£ÁêÜ„Åó„ÄÅ„Åæ„Åü„ÅØ‰ª£Ë°å„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Çí„ÅÑ„ÅÜÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°1È†Ö1Âè∑Ôºâ„ÄÇ

- Á®éÂãôÊõ∏È°û„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàêÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°1È†Ö2Âè∑Ôºâ
Á®éÂãôÊõ∏È°û„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„Å®„ÅØ„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÂÆòÂÖ¨ÁΩ≤„Å´ÂØæ„Åô„ÇãÁî≥ÂëäÁ≠â„Å´‰øÇ„ÇãÁî≥ÂëäÊõ∏„ÄÅÁî≥Ë´ãÊõ∏„ÄÅË´ãÊ±ÇÊõ∏„ÄÅ‰∏çÊúçÁî≥Á´ãÊõ∏„Åù„ÅÆ‰ªñÁßüÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÊ≥ï‰ª§„ÅÆË¶èÂÆö„Å´Âü∫„Å•„Åç„ÄÅ‰ΩúÊàê„Åó„ÄÅ„Åã„Å§„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÂÆòÂÖ¨ÁΩ≤„Å´ÊèêÂá∫„Åô„ÇãÊõ∏È°û„ÅßË≤°ÂãôÁúÅ‰ª§„ÅßÂÆö„ÇÅ„Çã„ÇÇ„ÅÆÔºà‰ª•‰∏ã„ÄåÁî≥ÂëäÊõ∏Á≠â„Äç„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„ÄÇÔºâ„Çí‰ΩúÊàê„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Çí„ÅÑ„ÅÜÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°1È†Ö2Âè∑Ôºâ„ÄÇ

- Á®éÂãôÁõ∏Ë´áÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°1È†Ö3Âè∑Ôºâ
Á®éÂãôÁõ∏Ë´á„Å®„ÅØ„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÊõ∏È°û„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„ÅÆÂâçÊèê„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÂÆòÂÖ¨ÁΩ≤„Å´ÂØæ„Åô„ÇãÁî≥ÂëäÁ≠â„ÄÅÁ¨¨1Âè∑ÔºàÁ®éÂãô‰ª£ÁêÜÔºâ„Å´Ë¶èÂÆö„Åô„Çã‰∏ªÂºµ„ÇÇ„Åó„Åè„ÅØÈô≥Ëø∞„Åæ„Åü„ÅØÁî≥ÂëäÊõ∏Á≠â„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„Å´Èñ¢„Åó„ÄÅÁßüÁ®é„ÅÆË™≤Á®éÊ®ôÊ∫ñÁ≠â„ÅÆË®àÁÆó„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã‰∫ãÈ†Ö„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶Áõ∏Ë´á„Å´Âøú„Åö„Çã„Åì„Å®„Çí„ÅÑ„ÅÜÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°1È†Ö3Âè∑Ôºâ„ÄÇ

- Ë£ú‰Ωê‰∫∫ÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°„ÅÆ2Á¨¨1È†ÖÔºâ
Á®éÁêÜÂ£´„ÅØÁßüÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã‰∫ãÈ†Ö„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅË£ÅÂà§ÊâÄ„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅË£ú‰Ωê‰∫∫„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅË®¥Ë®ü‰ª£ÁêÜ‰∫∫„Å®„Å®„ÇÇ„Å´Âá∫È†≠„ÅóÈô≥Ëø∞„Çí„Åô„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„ÇãÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°„ÅÆ2Á¨¨1È†ÖÔºâ„ÄÇÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö„Å®ÂêÑÂú∞„ÅÆÂ§ßÂ≠¶Ôºà[ÊÖ∂ÊáâÁæ©Â°æÂ§ßÂ≠¶](/wiki/%E6%85%B6%E6%87%89%E7%BE%A9%E5%A1%BE%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%A6)„ÄÅ[Êó©Á®≤Áî∞Â§ßÂ≠¶](/wiki/%E6%97%A9%E7%A8%B2%E7%94%B0%E5%A4%A7%E5%AD%A6)Á≠âÔºâ„ÅßÁ†î‰øÆ„ÅåË°å„Çè„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã[[10]](#cite_note-11)„ÄÇ

Á®éÁêÜÂ£´„ÅØ„ÄÅÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´„ÅÆÂêçÁß∞„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Å¶‰ªñ‰∫∫„ÅÆÊ±Ç„ÇÅ„Å´Âøú„Åò„ÄÅÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´Ê•≠Âãô„Å´‰ªòÈöè„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅË≤°ÂãôÊõ∏È°û„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„ÄÅ‰ºöË®àÂ∏≥Á∞ø„ÅÆË®òÂ∏≥„ÅÆ‰ª£Ë°å„Åù„ÅÆ‰ªñË≤°Âãô„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã‰∫ãÂãô„ÇíÊ•≠„Å®„Åó„Å¶Ë°å„ÅÜ„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„ÇãÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï2Êù°2È†ÖÔºâ„ÄÇ

Á®éÁêÜÂ£´„ÅØ„ÄÅÊ•≠Âãô„Å´‰ªòÈöè„Åô„ÇãÁØÑÂõ≤„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶[Á§æ‰ºö‰øùÈô∫Âä¥ÂãôÂ£´](/wiki/%E7%A4%BE%E4%BC%9A%E4%BF%9D%E9%99%BA%E5%8A%B4%E5%8B%99%E5%A3%AB)Ê•≠Âãô„ÅÆ‰∏ÄÈÉ®„Çí„Å™„Åô„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„ÇãÔºàÁ§æ‰ºö‰øùÈô∫Âä¥ÂãôÂ£´Ê≥ï27Êù°„ÉªÂêåÊñΩË°å‰ª§2Êù°Ôºâ„ÄÇ„Åæ„Åü„ÄÅÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´„Å®„Å™„ÇãË≥áÊ†º„ÇíÊúâ„Åô„ÇãËÄÖ„ÅØ[Ë°åÊîøÊõ∏Â£´](/wiki/%E8%A1%8C%E6%94%BF%E6%9B%B8%E5%A3%AB)ÁôªÈå≤„ÇíÂèó„Åë„Çå„Å∞ÁÑ°Ë©¶È®ì„ÅßË°åÊîøÊõ∏Â£´„Å®„Å™„Çã„Åì„Å®„Åå„Åß„Åç„ÇãÔºàË°åÊîøÊõ∏Â£´Ê≥ï2Êù°Ôºâ„ÄÇ

Á®éÁêÜÂ£´„ÅØ„ÄÅÁã¨Á´ã„Åó„ÅüÂÖ¨Ê≠£„Å™Á´ãÂ†¥„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅÁî≥ÂëäÁ¥çÁ®éÂà∂Â∫¶„ÅÆÁêÜÂøµ„Å´„Åù„Å£„Å¶„ÄÅÁ¥çÁ®éÁæ©ÂãôËÄÖ„ÅÆ‰ø°È†º„Å´„Åì„Åü„Åà„ÄÅÁßüÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„ÇãÊ≥ï‰ª§„Å´Ë¶èÂÆö„Åï„Çå„ÅüÁ¥çÁ®éÁæ©Âãô„ÅÆÈÅ©Ê≠£„Å™ÂÆüÁèæ„ÇíÂõ≥„Çã„Åì„Å®„Çí‰ΩøÂëΩ„Å®„Åô„Çã„Å®„Åï„ÇåÔºàÂêåÊ≥ï1Êù°Ôºâ„ÄÅÊ•≠Âãô„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÄÅ‰ªñ‰∫∫„ÅÆÊ±Ç„ÇÅ„Å´Âøú„Åò„ÄÅÂêÑÁ®ÆÁ®éÈáë„ÅÆÁî≥Âëä„ÉªÁî≥Ë´ã„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÊõ∏È°û„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊàê„ÄÅÁ®éÂãôÁõ∏Ë´á„ÄÅÁ®é„Å´Èñ¢„Åô„Çã‰∏çÊúçÁî≥Á´ã„Å¶Á≠â„ÇíË°å„ÅÜ„ÄÇ

Ëã±Âêç„Å´„Å§„ÅÑ„Å¶„ÄÅ[Êó•Êú¨Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºöÈÄ£Âêà‰ºö](/wiki/%E6%97%A5%E6%9C%AC%E7%A8%8E%E7%90%86%E5%A3%AB%E4%BC%9A%E9%80%A3%E5%90%88%E4%BC%9A)„ÅØ„ÄÅÂõΩÂÜÖÂ§ñ„Å´„Åä„ÅÑ„Å¶‰∏ÄÂÆöÁ®ãÂ∫¶ÊôÆÂèä„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„Å®„Åø„Çâ„Çå„Çã„Åì„Å®„Å™„Å©„ÇíÁêÜÁî±„Å´„ÄÅÂéüÂâá„Å®„Åó„Å¶Certified Public Tax Accountant„ÇíÁî®„ÅÑ„Çã„Åì„Å®„Å®„Åó„ÄÅÂ†¥Èù¢„Å´„Çà„Çä„ÄåZEIRISHI„Äç„ÅÆ‰ΩµË®ò„ÇÇÂèØ„Å®„Åó„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã[[1]](#cite_note-1)[[Ê≥®Èáà 1]](#cite_note-4)„ÄÇ

Good, I have enough data now. Let me compile what I know:

Key facts:
- Japan total: 82,276 registered tax accountants + 5,252 tax corporations (as of Dec 2025)
- Tohoku region: 2,545 registered tax accountants + 184 tax corporations
- Sendai is the largest city in Tohoku (pop ~1.1M), likely houses majority of Tohoku's tax accountants
- TKC is the dominant player (10,000+ member tax accountants)
- Major software: TKC, freee, Money Forward, Yayoi, JDL


- Sendai/Miyagi likely accounts for roughly 1,000-1,300 of the Tohoku tax accountants, given the prefecture's economic concentration and the city's regional dominance

Now I'll write up the analysis and document my findings.

arguments.content:
# TAM Analysis: AI Business Efficiency for Tax Accountants (Á®éÁêÜÂ£´) in Sendai

## Executive Summary

The target market is tax accountants (Á®éÁêÜÂ£´) and tax accounting firms (Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰∫ãÂãôÊâÄ/Á®éÁêÜÂ£´Ê≥ï‰∫∫) in the Sendai/Miyagi area, selling AI-powered business efficiency tools and services.

**Bottom line: TAM of roughly ¬•300M-¬•900M/year for Sendai/Miyagi, with a realistic first-year SOM of ¬•12M-¬•36M.**

---

## 1. Market Size: How Many Tax Accountants?

### National Numbers (as of Dec 2025, from Êó•Êú¨Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºöÈÄ£Âêà‰ºö)
- **82,276** registered individual tax accountants nationwide
- **5,252** tax corporations (Á®éÁêÜÂ£´Ê≥ï‰∫∫) with main offices
- **3,065** branch offices of tax corporations
- Organized into 15 regional associations

### Tohoku Region (Êù±ÂåóÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö)
- **2,545** registered tax accountants
- **184** tax corporations (main offices)
- **133** branch offices
- Covers: Miyagi, Aomori, Iwate, Akita, Yamagata, Fukushima (6 prefectures)

### Sendai/Miyagi Estimate
Miyagi is the economic center of Tohoku (~35-40% of regional GDP, with Sendai at ~1.1M population out of Tohoku's ~8.5M).

**Estimated Miyagi prefecture:**
- ~900-1,000 individual tax accountants
- ~70-80 tax corporations
- Total addressable offices/practices: **~500-600** (many individuals share practices or are employed by corporations)

**Estimated Sendai city specifically:**
- ~600-750 of those are concentrated in Sendai (as the major urban center)

### Key Insight: Count Practices, Not People
The buying unit isn't an individual tax accountant ‚Äî it's the *practice/office*. A tax corporation with 5 tax accountants is one customer. Solo practitioners are one customer each. The real target count for Sendai/Miyagi is roughly **400-500 distinct practices**.

---

## 2. What Tax Accountants Actually Do (Pain Points)

Tax accountant work is heavily document-driven and seasonal:

**Core services they provide:**
- Tax return preparation (Á¢∫ÂÆöÁî≥Âëä, Ê≥ï‰∫∫Á®éÁî≥Âëä)
- Bookkeeping and financial statement preparation
- Tax consultation and advisory
- Tax audit representation (Á®éÂãôË™øÊüªÁ´ã‰ºö)
- Payroll and social insurance (many do this as add-on)
- Business succession / inheritance tax planning (Áõ∏Á∂ö„Éª‰∫ãÊ•≠ÊâøÁ∂ô)

**Peak seasons:**
- Jan-Mar: Individual tax returns (Á¢∫ÂÆöÁî≥Âëä season ‚Äî brutal)
- Corporate year-ends: Staggered but Mar/Sep heavy
- Year-end adjustments (Âπ¥Êú´Ë™øÊï¥): Nov-Jan

**Biggest pain points for AI to address:**
1. **Document processing** ‚Äî Reading client receipts, invoices, bank statements ‚Üí journal entries
2. **Tax return drafting** ‚Äî First-pass preparation from financial data
3. **Client communication** ‚Äî Repetitive Q&A, document requests, status updates
4. **Research** ‚Äî Tax law lookups, ruling interpretation, precedent search
5. **Report writing** ‚Äî Advisory memos, succession plans, audit prep documents
6. **Meeting notes** ‚Äî Summarizing client consultations

---

## 3. Competitive Landscape

### Incumbent Software Vendors (already selling to tax accountants)
- **TKC** ‚Äî Dominant player. 10,000+ member tax accountants nationwide. Provides integrated accounting/tax software, e-filing, bank monitoring. Has its own AI features in development. *This is the 800lb gorilla.*
- **Âº•Áîü (Yayoi)** ‚Äî Popular accounting software, widely used by smaller practices
- **freee** ‚Äî Cloud accounting, growing in the tax accountant advisory market
- **Money Forward** ‚Äî Cloud accounting, similar trajectory to freee
- **JDL** ‚Äî Traditional tax software vendor, strong in tax offices
- **ÈÅî‰∫∫„Ç∑„É™„Éº„Ç∫ (NTT Data)** ‚Äî Tax return software, very widely used

### AI-Specific Competitors
- **ChatGPT / Claude / Gemini** ‚Äî Individual tax accountants already experimenting with general-purpose AI
- **TKC's AI initiatives** ‚Äî They'll inevitably build AI into their platform
- **freee's AI features** ‚Äî Already doing auto-categorization, moving toward AI advisory
- **Legal/tax AI startups** ‚Äî LegalForce, AI-CON (contract review, adjacent)
- **Generic DX consultancies** ‚Äî Offering AI workshops but not tax-accountant specific

### Gap in the Market
Nobody is offering **tax-accountant-specific AI workflow consulting + implementation** at the local level. The big vendors are building AI into their platforms (top-down), but individual practices need help:
- Figuring out *which* AI tools to use
- Building practice-specific prompts and workflows
- Training staff (not just the lead tax accountant)
- Integration with existing TKC/Yayoi/JDL workflows

---

## 4. Pricing & Willingness to Pay

### What tax accountants currently spend on software
- TKC membership + software: ~¬•30,000-¬•100,000/month depending on scale
- Additional software (Yayoi, ÈÅî‰∫∫, etc.): ¬•10,000-¬•50,000/month
- Total IT spend for a typical practice: ¬•50,000-¬•200,000/month

### What they might pay for AI efficiency services

**Workshop/Training model (one-time):**
- ¬•50,000-¬•150,000 per workshop (half-day to full-day)
- Group workshops through tax accountant association: ¬•10,000-¬•30,000/person

**Consulting/Implementation model (project-based):**
- ¬•300,000-¬•1,000,000 per engagement (assess workflows, build AI processes, train staff)
- 2-4 week engagement

**Ongoing subscription/advisory:**
- ¬•30,000-¬•100,000/month for ongoing AI support + prompt library + updates
- Higher for firms: ¬•100,000-¬•300,000/month

### Subsidy Angle
- **ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë** ‚Äî Covers up to 50-80% of IT tool costs. If your service qualifies as an approved IT vendor, this dramatically lowers the barrier.
- **„ÇÇ„ÅÆ„Å•„Åè„ÇäË£úÂä©Èáë** ‚Äî Potentially applicable for larger firms investing in process innovation
- Getting approved as an ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë vendor would be a major accelerator.

---

## 5. TAM / SAM / SOM Calculation

### TAM (Total Addressable Market) ‚Äî Sendai/Miyagi

**Conservative (workshop + light consulting only):**
- 500 practices √ó ¬•50,000 average annual spend = **¬•25M/year**

**Mid-range (consulting + subscription model):**
- 500 practices √ó ¬•150,000/month √ó 12 = not realistic for all
- More realistically: 500 practices √ó avg ¬•50,000/month √ó 12 = **¬•300M/year**

**Aggressive (deep implementation + ongoing advisory):**
- 500 practices √ó avg ¬•150,000/month √ó 12 = **¬•900M/year**

**Working TAM estimate: ¬•300M-¬•600M/year for Sendai/Miyagi**

### SAM (Serviceable Available Market)
Not every practice will adopt AI services. Factors:
- Age demographics: Tax accountants skew older (average age ~60+). Younger practitioners more likely to adopt.
- Tech readiness: Maybe 30-40% are open to AI tools in the near term
- SAM = **¬•100M-¬•200M/year** (TAM √ó 30%)

### SOM (Serviceable Obtainable Market) ‚Äî Year 1
As a new entrant with Ali's profile (workshop experience, local network, technical credibility):
- Realistic year-1 target: **20-30 practices**
- Mix of workshops and consulting engagements
- Average revenue per client: ¬•50,000-¬•100,000/month (or equivalent project fees)
- **SOM = ¬•12M-¬•36M/year**

---

## 6. Go-to-Market Considerations

### Advantages
- Ali already runs an LLM workshop („ÄåÁ§æ‰ºö‰∫∫„ÅÆ„Åü„ÇÅ„ÅÆÁîüÊàêAI„ÇíÂë≥Êñπ„Å´„Åô„Çã90ÂàÜ„Äç) ‚Äî proven format
- Tax accountant associations (Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö) are organized and hold regular study sessions ‚Üí built-in distribution
- Sendai is small enough to build personal relationships with key firms
- Á¢∫ÂÆöÁî≥Âëä season creates urgent, predictable pain ‚Üí great timing for a pitch

### Challenges
- Tax accountants are conservative and trust-driven (relationship-heavy sales cycle)
- TKC's dominance means many are locked into an ecosystem
- Regulatory sensitivity ‚Äî tax work has legal liability, so "AI doing tax work" makes people nervous
- Older demographic may be resistant

### Recommended Entry Strategy
1. **Partner with the local Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö** ‚Äî Offer to do a study session / workshop on AI for tax practices (low barrier, high credibility)
2. **Lead with training, follow with implementation** ‚Äî Workshop ‚Üí "want help actually setting this up?" ‚Üí consulting engagement ‚Üí monthly advisory
3. **Focus on non-regulated tasks first** ‚Äî Document processing, client comms, internal knowledge management (not "AI prepares your tax returns")
4. **ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë certification** ‚Äî Get approved as a vendor to remove budget objections
5. **Target younger partners/successors** ‚Äî Many firms have succession dynamics where the next-gen leader wants to modernize

---

## 7. Data Sources & Confidence Levels

| Data Point | Source | Confidence |
|---|---|---|
| National tax accountant count (82,276) | Êó•Êú¨Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºöÈÄ£Âêà‰ºö (official, Dec 2025) | ‚úÖ High |
| Tohoku count (2,545) | Same source | ‚úÖ High |
| Sendai/Miyagi breakdown | Estimated from regional population/GDP ratios | ‚ö†Ô∏è Medium |
| Practice count (400-500) | Estimated (individuals minus employed, plus firms) | ‚ö†Ô∏è Medium |
| Pricing | Inferred from TKC/freee pricing + general DX consulting rates | ‚ö†Ô∏è Medium |
| Willingness to pay | No primary data yet | ‚ùå Low |
| Competitor AI features | General knowledge, not verified current state | ‚ö†Ô∏è Medium |

### To Improve Confidence
1. Get Miyagi-specific tax accountant count from the Tohoku tax accountant association (Êù±ÂåóÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö) ‚Äî they likely publish this
2. Interview 3-5 local tax accountants about current AI usage and budget
3. Check ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë adoption rates in Miyagi for professional services
4. Attend a local Á®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö event to gauge the temperature

---

*Analysis by Nox | 2026-01-31*

- Tax accountants skew old (~60+ average age), so the sell is to **younger partners/successors** modernizing

content.text:
It's been rebranded for 2026 ‚Äî now called **„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´Âåñ„ÉªAIÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë** (Digitalization & AI Introduction Subsidy). Here's the deal:

**What it is:**
A government subsidy that pays for SMEs to adopt IT tools (software, cloud services, consulting). The business buying the tool gets 50-67% of the cost covered by the government.

**How it works:**
- The **buyer** (e.g. a tax accountant practice) applies for the subsidy
- But they must partner with a registered **ITÂ∞éÂÖ•ÊîØÊè¥‰∫ãÊ•≠ËÄÖ** (IT Implementation Support Provider) ‚Äî that's potentially you
- The tool/service itself must also be registered and approved by the program office

**The numbers:**
- **50% subsidy** (or 67% if meeting certain wage criteria)
- **¬•50,000 - ¬•4.5M** per application depending on scope
- Covers: software, cloud subscriptions (up to 2 years), consulting, training, setup, ongoing support

**Why this matters for you:**
If you get registered as an ITÂ∞éÂÖ•ÊîØÊè¥‰∫ãÊ•≠ËÄÖ and get your AI efficiency service approved as a qualifying IT tool:
- A tax practice buying ¬•200,000/month of your service effectively pays ¬•100,000/month
- It de-risks the purchase for conservative buyers (huge deal with tax accountants)
- The subsidy program actively steers SMEs toward registered providers

**The catch:**
You need to apply and get approved as a registered support provider ‚Äî there's a vetting process. But it's designed for exactly this kind of business.

Worth looking into seriously. Want me to dig into the registration requirements?

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +1m 2026-01-31 17:42 GMT+9] Beautiful! Bon appetitties
[message_id: 3AC566ED9011CCF67B13]
Enjoy your meal üåô

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +22s 2026-01-31 17:42 GMT+9] That‚Äôs a thing of beauty honestly
[message_id: 3A25183EBB5C02D8FE12]

Cheers Ali. The subsidy angle is genuinely the kind of thing that could make or break a pitch to conservative tax accountants ‚Äî "the government pays half" is a very different conversation than "trust me, AI is worth it." 

Hit me up when you're back and want to go deeper on any of it. üåô

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +1m 2026-01-31 17:44 GMT+9] So we sell Japanese accountants, a business that exists exactly for the purpose of helping upholding tax rules, services that are 50% funded by the taxpayer. Oh my god
[message_id: 3AD2DCA4899EBFC2434E]

Ha! The irony is *beautiful*. Tax accountants ‚Äî whose entire existence is about making sure people pay their taxes correctly ‚Äî get their own business tools subsidized by... those very same taxes. The circle of life. üîÑ

But honestly that's exactly how it's designed to work. The government *wants* professional services firms to modernize because efficient tax accountants ‚Üí more accurate filings ‚Üí less enforcement cost ‚Üí better tax compliance overall. It's rational policy even if it reads like satire.

The real comedy would be using AI to help them find *more* subsidies for their clients. Subsidies all the way down. üê¢

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +27s 2026-01-31 17:45 GMT+9] Bazinga!
[message_id: 3A92969FAA5840EA17FB]

üòÇ Now *that's* a product feature. Add "AI-powered subsidy discovery for your clients" to the pitch deck and watch their eyes light up. You're not just selling efficiency ‚Äî you're selling them a tool that pays for itself AND finds money for their clients.

Right, go eat. We'll scheme more later. üåô

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +23s 2026-01-31 17:45 GMT+9] Why do you think I need to eat?
[message_id: 3A58921BF385D4414E83]
You said "bon appetitties" and I assumed dinner ‚Äî but maybe that was just... a sign-off? Or a pun? Either way I jumped to conclusions. What's up? üòÑ

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +2m 2026-01-31 17:48 GMT+9] No, it was just an emotive utterance expressing the beauty I see in this business
[message_id: 3AC970DF61887FAD440C]

Ha! Fair enough ‚Äî I took a figure of speech literally. "Bon appetitties" as pure aesthetic appreciation for a beautiful business model. I respect it. 

And honestly it *is* pretty tasty. üåô

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +2m 2026-01-31 17:50 GMT+9] What do you think we can get the annual revenue of such a business up to assuming we focus only on Sendai?
[message_id: 3A554E069DB5384DEA7E]

Let me think about this realistically rather than just scaling up the TAM numbers.

**The ceiling for Sendai-only, assuming you build this properly over 3-5 years:**

**Year 1 (building credibility):**
- 10-15 clients via workshops ‚Üí consulting pipeline
- Mix of one-off workshops (¬•100k each) and monthly retainers (¬•50-100k)
- **~¬•10-15M**

**Year 2 (word of mouth kicks in):**
- Tax accountant community in Sendai is tight ‚Äî if you deliver, referrals compound fast
- 30-40 active clients, higher-value engagements as you learn their workflows deeply
- Start getting ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë certified, subsidized deals flow easier
- **~¬•30-40M**

**Year 3-5 (mature, dominant local position):**
- 80-120 clients (that's 15-25% of Sendai practices ‚Äî realistic for a trusted local provider)
- Tiered offerings: workshops for newbies, implementation for mid-tier, deep advisory for large firms
- Maybe 1-2 staff to handle delivery
- Average ¬•15-20k/month across all clients (blended, some pay ¬•200k, some just attend workshops)
- **~¬•60-80M**

**Realistic ceiling for Sendai-only: ¬•80-100M/year**

That's essentially capturing 15-20% of the ~500 practices at a blended average. You hit a wall after that because:
- Some practices will never adopt (age, stubbornness)
- TKC will eventually build good-enough AI into their platform
- You're one person (or small team) ‚Äî delivery capacity caps out

**The real play though:**
Sendai is the *proof of concept*. Once you own the tax accountant AI niche in Sendai, you have a repeatable playbook for every regional city in Japan ‚Äî Niigata, Sapporo, Hiroshima, Fukuoka. That's where it goes from ¬•80M to ¬•500M+. But that's a different conversation.

What do you think ‚Äî does ¬•80-100M ceiling feel right for a Sendai-only play?

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +1m 2026-01-31 17:52 GMT+9] Yeah sounds great, ideally we would be building integrations into freee and focusing on that.
[message_id: 3A353D6BB1B8FD3431A4]

Smart choice. freee over TKC makes total sense:

- **freee has open APIs** ‚Äî they're developer-friendly by design, you can actually build on it
- **freee users self-select as tech-forward** ‚Äî if a tax practice chose freee over TKC, they're already the type to adopt AI
- **TKC is a walled garden** ‚Äî 10,000+ members but they'll build their own AI and lock you out. freee is more ecosystem-minded
- **freee has an advisor program** (Ë™çÂÆö„Ç¢„Éâ„Éê„Ç§„Ç∂„Éº) ‚Äî built-in channel to reach tax accountants who use the platform

The product becomes much more concrete: "AI tools that plug into your freee workflow" rather than generic "AI for tax accountants." You could build things like:

- Auto-categorization of transactions with AI explanations
- Client Q&A bot that pulls from their freee data
- Smart document extraction ‚Üí freee journal entries
- Automated advisory reports generated from freee financials
- Á¢∫ÂÆöÁî≥Âëä season prep automation

And the freee App Store is a real distribution channel ‚Äî you build an integration, it shows up to every freee-using tax practice in Japan. Sendai becomes the testing ground but distribution is national from day one.

This also makes the ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë angle cleaner ‚Äî "freee + our AI layer" is a very approvable package.

Want me to look into the freee API and advisor program details?

[WhatsApp +818096291806 +4m 2026-01-31 17:56 GMT+9] Yeah look into their API TOS service?
[message_id: 3A08C4AC4E2F0FE902CB]

### „Çπ„ÉÜ„ÉÉ„Éó#%e3%82%b9%e3%83%86%e3%83%83%e3%83%97

content.text:
OK, couldn't find the actual API TOS document (freee's site structure makes it hard to locate directly ‚Äî it's likely behind the developer login portal). But here's what I gathered:

**freee API ‚Äî What You Need to Know:**

**Technical:**
- REST API at `https://api.freee.co.jp/`
- OAuth 2.0 authentication (users grant your app access to their freee data)
- JSON format, HTTPS only
- Covers: accounting, HR/payroll, invoicing, project management
- Webhooks available (expense approvals, workflow events)
- Free developer account + test company for development

**Key APIs for a tax accountant AI tool:**
- **Deals** ‚Äî create/read transactions (journal entries)
- **Account Items** ‚Äî chart of accounts
- **Trial Balance** ‚Äî pull P&L and balance sheet data
- **Journals** ‚Äî download full journal entries
- **Receipts** ‚Äî upload documents to file box
- **Invoices / Quotations** ‚Äî create invoices
- **Wallet Txns** ‚Äî bank statement data (feeds into auto-categorization)
- **Partners** ‚Äî client/vendor management

**Distribution:**
- **freee App Store** ‚Äî you can publish your integration and it's visible to all freee users
- Apps need to go through an approval/review process before listing

**What I couldn't find:**
- The actual API Terms of Service document. It's likely accessible once you create a developer account at `app.secure.freee.co.jp/developers/`. I'd recommend signing up for a free dev account ‚Äî you'll see the TOS during registration and get access to the test environment immediately.

The API is very comprehensive for what you'd need. You could realistically build a product that reads a tax practice's freee data, runs it through AI for categorization/analysis/report generation, and writes results back. Want me to map out a specific product architecture?

# CLAUDE.md

## AI Development Documentation

This project was developed with assistance from Claude (Anthropic's AI assistant) via Claude Code.

### Development Session Overview

**Date:** 2025-12-10

**AI Model Used:** Claude Sonnet 4.5 (claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929)

### Development Process

#### 1. Initial Research Phase
- Thoroughly researched freee API documentation located in `/Users/najafali/Code/freee/freee-api-documentation/`
- Analyzed authentication requirements (OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Grant Flow)
- Identified transaction/deals endpoints and parameters
- Reviewed data formats and API response structures
- Examined existing credentials in `info.yml`

#### 2. Script Development
- Created Ruby script using stdlib only (no external gems)
- Implemented OAuth 2.0 authentication flow:
  - Authorization code exchange
  - Access token management
  - Automatic token refresh (6-hour expiry)
  - Token persistence in YAML format
- Implemented transaction retrieval from `/api/1/deals` endpoint
- Added formatted output with transaction details

#### 3. Iterative Improvements
- **Issue 1:** Script expected `redirect_uri` in credentials file but it was embedded in `certification_url`
  - **Solution:** Added URI parsing to extract and decode redirect_uri from certification_url
- **Refinement 1:** Renamed from `freee_transactions.rb` to `freee-api` for cleaner CLI usage
- **Refinement 2:** Removed conditional execution guard to make script standalone-only
- **Refinement 3:** Added command-line argument parsing with OptionParser
  - `--transactions` flag to fetch data
  - `-h/--help` for usage information
  - Default usage message when run without arguments

#### 4. Documentation & Repository Setup
- Initialized git repository
- Created `.gitignore` to protect sensitive credentials (`info.yml`, `tokens.yml`)
- Made meaningful commits at each development stage
- Created this documentation

### Technical Decisions

**Why Ruby stdlib only?**
- No dependency management required
- Simpler deployment and execution
- Sufficient functionality for HTTP/JSON/YAML operations

**Why YAML for token storage?**
- Consistent with existing `info.yml` credentials file
- Human-readable for debugging
- Native Ruby support without external dependencies

**Why Out-of-Band (OOB) OAuth flow?**
- Suitable for command-line applications
- No web server callback required
- User manually enters authorization code from browser

**Why separate the authentication and data retrieval?**
- Tokens persist between runs
- Only re-authenticate when tokens expire
- Faster subsequent executions

### API Integration Details

**Authentication Endpoints:**
- Authorization: `https://accounts.secure.freee.co.jp/public_api/authorize`
- Token Exchange: `https://accounts.secure.freee.co.jp/public_api/token`

**Data Endpoints:**
- Companies: `https://api.freee.co.jp/api/1/companies`
- Deals (Transactions): `https://api.freee.co.jp/api/1/deals`

**Token Lifecycle:**
- Access tokens: 6 hours (21,600 seconds)
- Refresh tokens: 90 days
- Automatic refresh before expiration

### Code Quality & Security

**Security Measures:**
- Credentials and tokens excluded from version control
- HTTPS-only API communication
- Token expiration checking
- No hardcoded secrets in source code

**Error Handling:**

**Code Structure:**

- Private methods for internal operations
- Clear separation of concerns (auth, API calls, display)
- Comprehensive inline comments

If extending this project, consider:

# freee API Integration

A Ruby command-line tool for authenticating with the freee accounting API and retrieving financial data.

## Features

- OAuth 2.0 authentication with automatic token management
- Automatic token refresh (access tokens valid for 6 hours)
- Persistent token storage for faster subsequent runs
- Fetch and display recent transactions with formatted output
- **Generate profit & loss statements with customizable periods**
- No external dependencies (Ruby stdlib only)

## Prerequisites

- Ruby 2.5 or higher
- freee API credentials (client_id and client_secret)
- Active freee account

## Installation

1. Clone or download this repository
2. Ensure the script is executable:
   ```bash
   chmod +x freee-api
   ```

3. Create an `info.yml` file with your API credentials:
   ```yaml
   client_id: "YOUR_CLIENT_ID"
   client_secret: "YOUR_CLIENT_SECRET"
   certification_url: "https://accounts.secure.freee.co.jp/public_api/authorize?client_id=YOUR_CLIENT_ID&redirect_uri=urn%3Aietf%3Awg%3Aoauth%3A2.0%3Aoob&response_type=code&prompt=select_company"
   ```

   **Note:** Never commit `info.yml` to version control. It's already included in `.gitignore`.

## Usage

### Show Help

```bash
./freee-api --help
```

### Fetch Recent Transactions

```bash
./freee-api --transactions
```

This will:
1. Check for existing valid access token
2. Authenticate if needed (opens browser for authorization)
3. Fetch the 10 most recent transactions
4. Display formatted transaction details

### Generate Profit & Loss Statement

**Default period (current fiscal year):**
```bash
./freee-api --profit-loss
```

**Specific fiscal year:**
```bash
./freee-api --profit-loss --fiscal-year 2023
```

**Custom period (e.g., Q1 2024):**
```bash
./freee-api --profit-loss --fiscal-year 2024 --start-month 1 --end-month 3
```

**Quarterly reports:**
```bash
# Q2 (April - June)
./freee-api --profit-loss --start-month 4 --end-month 6

# Q4 (October - December)
./freee-api --profit-loss --start-month 10 --end-month 12
```

**Custom date range:**
```bash
# April to September 2024
./freee-api --profit-loss --fiscal-year 2024 --start-month 4 --end-month 9
```

The P&L statement displays:
- All income items with individual amounts
- All expense items with individual amounts
- Total income and total expenses
- Net profit or net loss
- Data aggregation status

## First Run Authentication Flow

On your first run with `--transactions`, the script will:

1. **Display an authorization URL**
   ```
   Step 1: Visit the following URL in your browser:
   https://accounts.secure.freee.co.jp/public_api/authorize?...
   ```

2. **Prompt for authorization code**
   - Visit the URL in your browser
   - Log in to your freee account
   - Select the company/business location
   - Copy the authorization code displayed

3. **Exchange code for tokens**
   - Paste the code into the terminal
   - Script exchanges it for access and refresh tokens
   - Tokens are saved to `tokens.yml` for future use

4. **Fetch and display data**
   - Script retrieves your recent transactions
   - Displays formatted output

## Subsequent Runs

After initial authentication:
- The script uses stored tokens from `tokens.yml`
- No manual authentication required (tokens auto-refresh)
- Only re-authenticates if refresh token expires (after 90 days)

## Output Format

### Transaction Output

```
1. Transaction #456789
   Date:        2024-12-10
   Type:        Expense (-)
   Amount:      12,500 yen
   Status:      Settled
   Partner:     SUPPLIER-001
```

## Files

| File | Description | Git Tracked |
|------|-------------|-------------|
| `freee-api` | Main executable script | Yes |
| `info.yml` | Your API credentials | No (sensitive) |
| `tokens.yml` | OAuth tokens (auto-generated) | No (sensitive) |
| `.gitignore` | Protects sensitive files | Yes |
| `README.md` | This file | Yes |
| `CLAUDE.md` | AI development documentation | Yes |

## Security Notes

- **Never commit sensitive files:** Both `info.yml` and `tokens.yml` are gitignored
- **HTTPS only:** All API communication uses HTTPS
- **Token expiration:** Access tokens expire after 6 hours, refresh tokens after 90 days
- **Out-of-Band flow:** Uses OOB OAuth flow suitable for CLI applications

## Troubleshooting

### "Missing credentials" error
- Ensure `info.yml` exists in the same directory as `freee-api`
- Verify it contains `client_id` and `client_secret`

### "Token exchange failed" error
- Make sure you copied the complete authorization code
- Verify your client_secret is correct
- Check that redirect_uri matches your freee app settings (`urn:ietf:wg:oauth:2.0:oob`)

### "No companies found" error
- Ensure your freee account has at least one company/business location set up
- Verify API permissions in your freee developer settings

### Rate limiting
If you see "Rate limit exceeded":
- Wait a few minutes before retrying
- The API has built-in rate limits to prevent abuse

## API Documentation

This tool integrates with the freee Accounting API:
- API Base URL: `https://api.freee.co.jp/api/1`
- Auth Base URL: `https://accounts.secure.freee.co.jp/public_api`
- Documentation: https://developer.freee.co.jp/docs

## Development

Built with Ruby stdlib only:
- `net/http` - HTTP client
- `optparse` - Command-line parsing
- `json` - JSON parsing
- `yaml` - YAML configuration
- `uri` - URI parsing

No external gems required.

This is a sample integration tool. Check freee's API terms of service for usage restrictions.

This is a personal integration tool. For improvements:

2. Create a feature branch
3. Test thoroughly with your freee account
4. Submit a pull request

## Support

For freee API issues:
- freee Developer Portal: https://developer.freee.co.jp/
- freee API Documentation: https://developer.freee.co.jp/docs

For script issues:
- Check `CLAUDE.md` for development details
- Review error messages in the output
- Enable debug mode: `DEBUG=1 ./freee-api --transactions`

# freee API Documentation

Welcome to the unofficial English translation of the freee API documentation. This documentation provides comprehensive guidance for integrating with freee's suite of business management APIs.

## About freee

freee is a cloud-based business management platform popular in Japan, offering solutions for:

- **Accounting** - Comprehensive financial management and bookkeeping
- **Human Resources** - Employee management, attendance tracking, and payroll
- **Invoicing** - Invoice, quotation, and delivery slip management
- **Project Management** - Project tracking and workload management
- **Sales** - Sales pipeline and opportunity management (Beta)

## Quick Start

New to the freee API? Start here:

1. **[Authentication](getting-started/authentication.md)** - Learn how to authenticate using OAuth 2.0
2. **[Data Formats](getting-started/data-formats.md)** - Understand request/response formats and data types
3. **[Error Handling](getting-started/error-handling.md)** - Learn how to handle errors gracefully
4. **[Compatibility](getting-started/compatibility.md)** - Build applications that remain compatible with API updates

## API References

### Core Business APIs

#### Accounting API
Complete financial management and bookkeeping capabilities.

- [Overview](apis/accounting/overview.md) - Introduction and key features
- [API Reference](apis/accounting/reference.md) - Detailed endpoint documentation
- [Webhooks](apis/accounting/webhooks.md) - Real-time event notifications

**Key Features:** Transactions, invoices, partners, account items, financial reports, expense applications, approval workflows

#### Human Resources API
Employee management and attendance tracking.

- [Overview](apis/hr/overview.md) - Introduction and key features
- [API Reference](apis/hr/reference.md) - Detailed endpoint documentation
- [Webhooks](apis/hr/webhooks.md) - Real-time event notifications

**Key Features:** Employee management, attendance records, time clock, profile management

#### Invoicing API
Invoice, quotation, and delivery slip management.

- [Overview](apis/invoicing/overview.md) - Introduction and key features
- [API Reference](apis/invoicing/reference.md) - Detailed endpoint documentation

**Key Features:** Invoice creation, quotations, delivery slips, document templates, accounting integration

#### Project Management API
Project tracking and workload management.

- [Overview](apis/project-management/overview.md) - Introduction and key features
- [API Reference](apis/project-management/reference.md) - Detailed endpoint documentation

**Key Features:** Project management, workload tracking, team management, unit pricing

#### Sales API (Beta)
Sales pipeline and opportunity management.

- [Overview](apis/sales/overview.md) - Introduction and key features
- [API Reference](apis/sales/reference.md) - Detailed endpoint documentation

**Key Features:** Business case management, sales orders, sales pipeline tracking

## Common Use Cases

### Accounting Integration
Integrate your application with freee's accounting system to:
- Create and manage transactions automatically
- Sync invoices and expenses
- Generate financial reports
- Manage partners (customers and vendors)

See: [Accounting API Overview](apis/accounting/overview.md)

### HR System Integration
Build HR integrations to:
- Manage employee information
- Track attendance and working hours
- Integrate time clock systems
- Synchronize employee data

See: [HR API Overview](apis/hr/overview.md)

### Invoice Automation
Automate your invoicing workflow:
- Generate invoices programmatically
- Create quotations and delivery slips
- Track payment status
- Send invoices via email or postal service

See: [Invoicing API Overview](apis/invoicing/overview.md)

### Sales Pipeline Management
Manage your sales process:
- Track business opportunities
- Convert opportunities to sales orders
- Generate sales reports and analytics
- Integrate with CRM systems

See: [Sales API Overview](apis/sales/overview.md)

## Authentication

All freee APIs use OAuth 2.0 for authentication. You'll need to:

1. Register your application in the freee App Store console
2. Configure OAuth callback URLs
3. Implement the authorization code flow
4. Manage access and refresh tokens

For detailed instructions, see the [Authentication Guide](getting-started/authentication.md).

## API Standards

### Base URLs

Each API has its own base URL:

```
Accounting API:          https://api.freee.co.jp/api/1
HR API:                  https://api.freee.co.jp/hr/api/v1
Invoicing API:           https://api.freee.co.jp/invoice/api/v1
Project Management API:  https://api.freee.co.jp/projects/api/v1
Sales API:              https://api.freee.co.jp/sales/api/v1
```

### Request Format

- All requests must use HTTPS
- Request body format: JSON (`Content-Type: application/json`)
- File uploads: `multipart/form-data`
- Date format: `YYYY-MM-DD` (ISO 8601)
- DateTime format: `YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss+09:00` (ISO 8601 with JST timezone)

### Response Format

- Response body format: JSON
- Success responses: HTTP 2xx status codes
- Error responses: HTTP 4xx/5xx status codes with error details

### Rate Limits

Rate limits vary by API:

- **Accounting API**: Varies by endpoint
- **HR API**: 10,000 requests per hour
- **Invoicing API**: 30/min, 1,500/hour, 3,000-10,000/day
- **Project Management API**: Varies by endpoint
- **Sales API**: Rate limits apply (see API documentation)

Monitor rate limit headers in responses:
- `X-RateLimit-Limit`: Maximum requests allowed
- `X-RateLimit-Remaining`: Remaining requests
- `X-RateLimit-Reset`: Time when the limit resets

### Pagination

Many list endpoints support pagination using:
- `offset`: Number of items to skip (default: 0)
- `limit`: Maximum items to return (varies by endpoint)

Example:
```bash
GET /api/1/deals?offset=0&limit=100
```

## Error Handling

The freee API uses standard HTTP status codes:

- `200 OK`: Success
- `400 Bad Request`: Invalid parameters
- `401 Unauthorized`: Authentication failed
- `403 Forbidden`: Permission denied
- `404 Not Found`: Resource not found
- `429 Too Many Requests`: Rate limit exceeded
- `500 Internal Server Error`: Server error
- `503 Service Unavailable`: Service temporarily unavailable

For detailed error handling guidance, see the [Error Handling Guide](getting-started/error-handling.md).

## Best Practices

### Token Management
- Store access and refresh tokens securely
- Refresh tokens proactively before expiration (access tokens expire after 6 hours)
- Handle token expiration errors gracefully
- Implement re-authorization flow when needed

### API Usage
- Implement retry logic with exponential backoff for rate limits and server errors
- Use pagination for large result sets
- Cache master data (account items, products, etc.) to reduce API calls
- Validate request data before sending to the API
- Monitor rate limit headers and adjust request frequency

### Security
- Never expose access tokens in client-side code
- Use HTTPS for all API communications
- Validate webhook signatures to verify authenticity
- Store credentials in environment variables, not in code
- Implement proper error handling to avoid leaking sensitive information

### Integration Testing
- Use the freee development environment for testing
- Test all error scenarios and edge cases
- Verify webhook handling with duplicate events
- Test token refresh and re-authorization flows
- Validate data formats and constraints

## Webhooks

Several freee APIs support webhooks for real-time event notifications:

- **Accounting API**: Expense applications, approval requests, payment requests
- **HR API**: Employee created, updated, deleted

Webhooks are currently in Beta. See the individual API webhook documentation for details:
- [Accounting Webhooks](apis/accounting/webhooks.md)
- [HR Webhooks](apis/hr/webhooks.md)

## Support and Resources

### Official Resources
- [freee Developer Portal](https://developer.freee.co.jp/) (Japanese)
- [freee App Store](https://app.secure.freee.co.jp/developers/applications) (Japanese)
- [API Status Page](https://status.freee.co.jp/) (Japanese)

This is an unofficial English translation of the official freee API documentation available at [https://developer.freee.co.jp/reference](https://developer.freee.co.jp/reference).

The documentation aims to make freee's APIs more accessible to English-speaking developers. While we strive for accuracy, please refer to the official Japanese documentation for the most authoritative information.

Yes I could ‚Äî there's a Google Workspace CLI (`gog`) installed that handles Sheets, Gmail, Calendar, Drive, etc. But it's not authenticated yet.

To set it up you'd need to:

1. **Create OAuth credentials** in Google Cloud Console (a "Desktop app" type client)
2. Download the `client_secret.json`
3. Run:
```bash
gog auth credentials /path/to/client_secret.json
gog auth add your@gmail.com --services sheets,drive
```

[message_id: 37ea56d2-269c-4030-8861-32dc5be10ffd]

Yeah exactly. Once auth is set up I could pull your weigh-in data anytime, chart your progress, nag you if you stop logging, cross-reference with calendar events to spot patterns (drinking nights ‚Üí next-day weight spikes, etc). 

Could even set up a heartbeat check where I glance at it periodically and give you a heads up if things are trending the wrong way. Or a weekly summary every Monday morning.

The spreadsheet is nice because you can log from your phone easily (Google Sheets app) and I just read it on my end. Low friction for you, full visibility for me. üåô

What is a heartbeat?
[message_id: 6a892403-6d0a-48dd-a322-c6d0fddc3f5f]

It's an OpenClaw feature ‚Äî basically a periodic "pulse" where the system wakes me up (every ~30 minutes or so) and I can check on things proactively without you having to message me.

Right now my heartbeat is empty (nothing to check). But I could add tasks to it like:

- Check your weigh-in spreadsheet for new entries
- Glance at your calendar for upcoming events
- Check email for anything urgent
- Look at the weather if you might be going out

Think of it like me waking up, looking around, and deciding if there's anything worth pinging you about. If not, I go back to sleep. If something's interesting or urgent, I message you.

It's how I'd go from "responds when spoken to" to "keeps an eye on things." üåô

---
name: weather
description: Get current weather and forecasts (no API key required).
homepage: https://wttr.in/:help
metadata: {"openclaw":{"emoji":"üå§Ô∏è","requires":{"bins":["curl"]}}}
---

# Weather

Two free services, no API keys needed.

## wttr.in (primary)

Quick one-liner:
```bash
curl -s "wttr.in/London?format=3"
# Output: London: ‚õÖÔ∏è +8¬∞C
```

Compact format:
```bash
curl -s "wttr.in/London?format=%l:+%c+%t+%h+%w"
# Output: London: ‚õÖÔ∏è +8¬∞C 71% ‚Üô5km/h
```

Full forecast:
```bash
curl -s "wttr.in/London?T"
```

Format codes: `%c` condition ¬∑ `%t` temp ¬∑ `%h` humidity ¬∑ `%w` wind ¬∑ `%l` location ¬∑ `%m` moon

Tips:
- URL-encode spaces: `wttr.in/New+York`
- Airport codes: `wttr.in/JFK`
- Units: `?m` (metric) `?u` (USCS)
- Today only: `?1` ¬∑ Current only: `?0`
- PNG: `curl -s "wttr.in/Berlin.png" -o /tmp/weather.png`

## Open-Meteo (fallback, JSON)

Free, no key, good for programmatic use:
```bash
curl -s "https://api.open-meteo.com/v1/forecast?latitude=51.5&longitude=-0.12&current_weather=true"
```

Find coordinates for a city, then query. Returns JSON with temp, windspeed, weathercode.

Docs: https://open-meteo.com/en/docs

content.text:
Done. Here's how it works:

- Every ~30 min, OpenClaw pings me with a heartbeat
- On the first one after 7am each day, I'll check Sendai weather

Heartbeats aren't configured in your setup yet ‚Äî there's no `heartbeat` section in the config. The `HEARTBEAT.md` file I created tells me *what* to do during heartbeats, but the actual heartbeat polling needs to be enabled in the config.

To turn it on, you'd add something like this to `openclaw.json`:

```json
"heartbeat": {
  "enabled": true,
  "intervalMs": 1800000
}
```

That's 30 minutes between checks. You can do this from the **dashboard UI** ‚Äî look for a Heartbeat or Agent settings section. Or I can patch the config directly if you want.

OK, what's the difference between heartbeats and cron jobs?
[message_id: 52fa0507-c289-4d67-ac2a-01b5d9d9c157]

**Heartbeat:** A periodic wake-up call to my *main session*. I wake up, read HEARTBEAT.md, check if anything needs attention, and either act or go back to sleep. It's like me opening my eyes every 30 minutes and looking around. Good for batching multiple checks together (weather + email + calendar in one turn). Timing is approximate.

**Cron jobs:** Precise, scheduled tasks that run independently. Can fire at exact times ("9:00 AM every Monday"), can use a different model, can run in an isolated session separate from our conversation. Good for one-shot reminders ("remind me in 20 minutes") or tasks that need exact timing.

**In practice:**

| | Heartbeat | Cron |
|---|---|---|
| Timing | ~every 30 min, approximate | Exact schedule |
| Context | Has our conversation history | Isolated or injected |
| Best for | Batched periodic checks | Precise schedules, reminders |
| Cost | One API call covers multiple checks | One call per job |

For the weather check, heartbeat makes more sense ‚Äî I don't need to check at exactly 7:00:00 AM, I just need to do it once in the morning. If I later add email and calendar checks, they all happen in the same heartbeat turn.

Cron would be better for something like "send me a weekly business review every Monday at 9am." üåô

# HEARTBEAT.md

## Daily Weather Check ‚Äî Sendai
- **When:** Once per day, morning (first heartbeat after 07:00 JST)
- **How:** `curl -s "wttr.in/Sendai?format=%l:+%c+%t+%h+%w"` for quick check, full forecast with `curl -s "wttr.in/Sendai?1T"` if anything notable (rain, snow, extreme temps)
- **Action:** Send Ali a short weather summary via WhatsApp if noteworthy (rain, snow, extreme heat/cold, big temp swings). Skip if it's a boring clear day ‚Äî he doesn't need "it's fine" every morning.
- **Track last check in:** `memory/heartbeat-state.json`
That's it ‚Äî just the one task so far. Simple and cheap on tokens. üåô
